Now that was a fun trip.
I watched Ben-to initially out of a need for something action-packed and fun. Prior to this, I had been burning myself out on, 'slice of life,' and 'comedy,' focused shows so this was actually a welcome experience.
Story: I suppose the story on it's base isn't particularly interesting or fascinating, but the idea of a bunch of students battling for a money saving meal is fun. The way this premise is turned into an epic battle over territories and pride just makes the pay-off feel satisfying. If you like the declaration of values before a big fight, than you're on theright track.


Art: Having been lucky enough to watch the show in 720p on a capable computer I will say that the art is pretty eye-candy. The action is fast and the character designs (while generic at times,) are fun to watch in motion. The art for some of the bento's had me drooling, so that's also a plus.


Sound: Well, the voices were appropriate. I especially liked Hana's voice acting because it sounded like the actress was having fun at times. The themes are the average J-Pop songs that are to be expected. 


Character: I liked the variety, personally. Even though I am familiar with the archetypes, the way the characters dance out their lines and actions was enjoyable. I must also mention that Yarizuri isn't your average melancholy upperclassman, but also shows a bit of emotion.


Enjoyment: Bias warning! I watched this show with a hope for fun, over-the-top action and guess what? It delivered. The premise is wacky enough and the character interactions are funny and enjoyable. Overall, I would have to say that the characters create the world they wish to portray. 


Overall: Listen, if you are like me and seek the occasional wacky, over-the-top, epic anime about a subject matter that seems banal 95% of the time, than you will find this show to be a joy. This is a fun series that only takes itself seriously when need be in order to up the 'epic,' factor. It was a blast!


Also, shout-outs to Satou for having a Fantasy Zone poster being displayed proudly. I respect that Sega love, ha.

This is one of those anime shows where the quality triples without fan service.
The story is simple and doesn't need to be good because it isn't that kind of show. The art is like the majority of anime and the VOs are actually pretty good IMO. There are too many female characters and the jokes are way too try hard and unnecessary. However I thought the action scenes were pretty damn good and the concept is quite nice as well. If you're wondering, it's basically a fight club over cheap food, so people with low budgets (mostly students) can eat decently. The MC gets draggedinto it and has a great time. Overall, if you ignore the fanservice this is a pretty good anime to watch.

When I first read the plot of this anime, I believed it would be hilarious. I got my hopes up and decided to watch it. It was nice, but it wasn't what I expected.
The story was somewhat mediocre. Fight Club-style battles that take place in supermarkets and grocery stores for various products. Gangs fight with each other and their leaders take the stamps of vegetables, fruits etc as trophies of their victory. The story sounds pretty shallow and in order to upgrade it, they gave an unessecary depth and showered the anime with tons of useless details. It could have been better off without them.
Whenit comes to art, there is a good amount of fanservice for those interested. The battle scenes are well coordinated and depicted nicely without too much confusion. The character models are unique for each person and their styles are different. Not a bad job there.


The soundtrack is very poor, consisting of only a couple of tracks. Although the battle theme is really neat and has a lot of energy in it, I don't think it fits well for grocery store beat-up. They could have chosen something better and add some more tunes.


The characters are, at least most of them, cheesy. Nearly all members of the female cast exist to satisfy your fanservice needs (luckily, they achieved that), while the male ones are predictable, lacking depth and development. Nothing impressive there.


Most possibly you will enjoy this one, since it combines weird plot with a nice dose of fanservice with cheap, easy but impossible to resist humour. It's not bad, it will give you a good laugh but you will find yourself wondering "has my IQ dropped after watching this?". Watch it if you got nothing better to do.

Single season anime based on light novels are a dime a dozen, enough of them having come out in the past five years to oversaturate the market with mediocrity. That said, I’ve found that around eighty or ninety percent of these anime are given the same score by me. Every time I give this sort of anime a solid six out of ten. And I know I’ve just spoiled the entire review in the first paragraph now, but I feel that it’s worth discussing how light novels influence anime and anime produced about light novels are so boringly adequate. Light novels themselves are typically badlywritten scripts for anime, thrown together in book form with the occasional illustration. That isn’t the case with many (Spice and Wolf and Haruhi Suzumiya are among the very few light novels I can recommend) but the ones that get turned into anime are very often that way.  The Devil is a Part Timer, Aria the Scarlet Ammo, Ben-To, Haiyore! Nyaruko-San. And let me iterate that all of these have good ideas behind them. The devil works at McDonalds, a high school for detectives, people battling for half-priced bento boxes, Lovecraftian horrors come to Earth as cute girls. But each and every one of these is executed poorly beyond that good idea. Most of them contain a very boring main male lead who we as an audience are supposed to put ourselves in the shoes of. Which is how these anime and light novels succeed: they’re fantasy simulators. If you make the lead character the most boring, characterless person possible, the male viewer or reader can stick himself in the role.


The problems being, beyond that, these anime have no savory components. The initial idea is typically very inventive or funny, but the execution is flawed beyond that. Aside from the main lead comes a cast of varied females, the more the merrier (and the more varied, the more male viewers). The plot plods along, introducing new arcs every few episodes to keep the viewer engaged. But, by four or five episodes in, the series has lost the initial pleasure and its’ existence becomes merely arbitrary.


Thus, Ben-To. How can a guy write nine novels (so far) around the concept of battles taking place in Japanese supermarkets for the half priced bento boxes sold before close? Especially when an anime that covers two of the novels overstays its’ welcome? The first episode and the initial revelation that this is an anime about mosh-pit style brawls over half priced lunch boxes is absolutely hilarious and clever. But then it keeps going, introducing gangs and federations that band together to fight for the bento, then twins who are so powerful no one can beat them. That’s the extent of the plot. This weak plot is padded with the prerequisite pool episode that further exemplifies the generic quality. It’s almost like these anime are factory made, though with a small difference in the mold to fit the plot or characters better.This generecism is further compounded with the tsundere, the kuudere, the yaoi-obsessed sex fiend, the lesbian, the incestuous twins, and the dorky klutz characters who round out a cast cut and pasted from many other series of the same quality.


That said, Ben-To can be enjoyable. It’s definitely occasionally funny and the fight scenes are well animated and better than anime with four times Ben-To’s budget. At the same time, the animation is still pretty cheap and generic, managing to make the girls cute as hell but not make anything else stand-out. And while the animation plays to the girls’ benefit, it’d help if the script and character development made these cute girls memorable. Rather than build up any of the characters, it decides to instead subject us to pointless lesbianism, a lot of worthless episodes and fights, and pretty much two arcs that could be resolved in one episode but are instead spread out like a pea sized glob of butter over toast.


It’s the kind of anime I can easily dismiss if I wanted to. It’s an easy target to abuse. But at the same time, it’s really not that bad. In the grand scheme of things, it manages to be entertaining without being very good. It’s funny, it’s cute a lot of times, and it’s a decent way to pass a few hours.  Would I suggest it? No. Would I suggest buying the recently released Blu-Ray? No. For certain people, they’ll find a lot of enjoyment in it. But I don’t see a lot of merits within. An anime can’t survive exclusively on cute characters and one good idea. As much as I love cuteness and girls in short skirts and long socks, there has to be substance beyond thighs and boobs. And that substance can come from a well-executed plot, character development, or even good comedy or world building. But Ben-To is exceptionally shallow and average in all four of those areas.  It’s a good average, but good average isn’t really a compliment.


I don’t have much to say about Ben-To because it doesn’t give me much reason to say anything. And typically an anime like that can be dismissed as average. If you can’t complain about how bad it is or rave about how good it is,  then it’s merely there. And that’s Ben-To in a nutshell, it’s just there.

Everybody eats food, especially teenagers. Personally, I list eating as a hobby. This anime takes eating to a whole new level. The God of Discounts comes out every night at convinient stores to put discount stickers on bentos. The moment he disappears into the back, and all out melee begins as financially restricted high school students known as Wolves fight each other for the boxes, using everything from chopsticks to shopping carts as weapons. However, it is not a meaningless brawl, but one of respect and honor with rules to be respected. Satou Yo experiences this firsthand when he sees a discount bento and unwittinglyenters the fray only to be promptly hospitalized. He meets the Ice Queen, or Yarizui-senpai, president of the Half-Priced Food Lovers Club. She offers to teach him the ways of the Wolves so he may partake in the fight not only for food, but honor and righteousness. \n\n
This anime is comedic, serious, and has you sitting on the edge of your seat the whole time. The fights are amazingly animated down to sweat flying, and they are accompanied by an awesome sound track. If you want a comedic action anime with a happy ending and a little bit of ecchi, this is your anime.

>THIS ANIME GETS BETTER AFTER A FEW EPISODES<
When you begin watching this anime you will have to swallow a very large stupid pill.
With that said, this anime is literally about a dude growing some balls as he discovers that the fights for half price bento are more than just pointless fights. After much time, he discovers the fight is a means of satisfaction, like a fight club, in which the winner is rewarded with a wonderful, and delicious prize.
The premise of this anime is literally beating the shit out of each other of food. With that said, THE ANIMATION OF THE FIGHTS IS THE BESTI"VE SEEN, even better than half of the anime ABOUT BATTLING. This anime also features very good dialogue between characters, giving me a fantastic laugh with its amazing euphemisms. The MC surprisingly, is a whimp! Oh wait i forgot what a suprize is. Seriously doe he grows some serious balls later.

So here's the thing... I don't think this show is very good, and that is rather bothersome, seeing as how this series held the potential to be very entertaining (which is mostly was, do not mistake this as me suggesting I did not enjoy it.) The biggest problem with this show for me was that it sold itself on the premise of a ridiculous action show, and every episode worked towards a climax to such a tune. While it did a justifiably entertaining job when geared towards a silly action-packed romp, in my opinion, the show shined brightest during the quiet comedic slice-of-life moments, andthis became problematic for me. I'll try to elaborate more clearly as I delve into the review.


Story: 7.


I ended up giving the story a 7 because it is an entertaining shot that just barely misses the mark. This leaves it in a "good," place for me; not great, not awful, just good. For example, the show is 100% built on an absurd premise: extreme fighting over half-priced bentos. The absurdity of this claim rests entirely upon how exactly wild the fighting is, and unfortunately for me, the fighting was often a bit tame for what the premise seemed to promise, initially. This forced me to instead fixate on the story outside of the actual fighting, in which case the show became a school-life anime, and this better delivered the absurdity, to me. The constant assaults, perverted misfortunes (cliche, but I'll always laugh at someone running around naked, call me old-fashioned) and miscommunications were always great. At the end of the day though, if I wanted a funny school-life anime, I would pick through the plethora out there that focus on doing exactly that more thoroughly. Perhaps I am just being picky (but that is, after-all, the point of a review?) but I wish the show would have had more interesting and crazy fights, instead of a few punches and kicks. It paid ample homage to fighting shows in many ways (including the obvious "alias" for fighting) but no one had a signature move and worst of all, the character's perceived power levels fluctuated so drastically between episodes I actually never got around to getting a head for ranking the fighters. I'll elaborate on that more in "Character." In all honesty, this show flung itself in-between two other shows that have a similar feel to me: Shokugeki and Dagashi Kashi. I believe that Shokugeki succeeds as the superior anime because (while the characters are a bit more fleshed out and nontraditional) it sticks to its premise and delivers absurdity expertly plated for the audience. The entire show is funny and entertaining, just like Ben-To, but where they differ is when Shokugeki begins a fight, I am 100% on board and in the moment. For Ben-To, the fights sort of run together and fizzle out. Ben-To succeeds against Dagashi Kashi though, in my opinion, because it does not focus too much on the slice of life aspect like Dagashi did. The absurd nature of all three of these shows does well with some "real life," basis in the plot line, but Dagashi captured the monotony of real life in its pacing, whereas Shokugeki is electric the whole way through, and Ben-To bounces between interesting moments for me. The final flaw for me is that there is no looming plotline throughout the story. The plot is literally just getting some cheap food when hungry, and this just brings us back to the issue I have between viewing it as an unsuccessful slice-of-life. There are moments hinted at, such as The Wizard's cryptic study abroad or Monarch Butterfly's past with the games. These are never elaborated on really though (I assume the manga does so much better) and the show ultimately suffers as being seen as episodic, which is not generally my half-priced cup of tea. 


Art: 9.


While I am not educated in art technique, I can at least say that this was a pretty anime and it did not rely on heavy CGI graphics or budget shots, which is a particular pet-peeve of mine. The colors were vivid, the animation was smooth, and the character design was attractive.


Sound: 7.


The voice acting was professional, and the score was always fitting. I gave a 7 because no voice actor, song, or moment in the score stood out enough for me to recognize that, and to that, I must assume it just did a good job and succeeded in fulfilling the requirements of all three areas of sound.


Character: 8.


I've been going back and forth on my rating for this, but I think I'll just start speaking now and stop second-guessing myself. I gave this series an 8, and surprisingly, I did so for the secondary characters, not the main characters. Satou, Shaga, and Yarizui are all just tropes, and I loved them for the exact same reason I have always loved them. The fool with an iron will and a heart of gild, the cold "Kuudere," character who is detatched from the world but somehow warm to the main character, and of course a healthy sprinkling of cousin-complex love interest that is never viewed as one. These are fine archetypes, and we keep them around for a reason, but I often prefer them as secondary characters, leaving us with more dynamic and individual main characters. This show does the opposite for me, in that while Oshiroi and Asabi are both static secondary characters, they consistently had me dying with laughter as the absurdity of the character. I think the reason why this works so well is because, as I have probably said too many times by this point, this is to be an absurd show, and these two characters are by far the most absurd. As a matter of fact, these two dominated the comedy for me, most of the time, and was just another hanging factor that made me feel like I was just missing something from this show. My biggest complaint though was unreliable power levels. Satou gets demolished his first fight, but then very quickly into the series is shown as an able fighter, beating people known to be stronger than him. My problem with this is that even after defeating Nikaidou and Monarch, he still does not seem to have a name (aliases or otherwise). Later, he is thrashed instantly on two separate occasions by Othros, but then shows up the third time and it is implied (with a Laurel sticker) that he beats both of them himself, when two days prior and with no special training he could not beat them even with the help of the "unbeatable" Ice Cold Witch. Monk, Hairdye, and other guy (?) also seem to slip in and out of being actually powerful, and they still call him "pooch," (a slightly derogatory name for a newcomer) even though he has obviously proven himself a more able warrior. This constant power shifting did not sit well with me, nor did the decision to not mention a single time how Satou was getting stronger, which would have been a logical direction to take since Yarizui was literally his club president and always with him. In my mind, this opaqueness of character hurt them in my eyes and did not allow me to fully suspend my disbelief in order to truly enjoy the show.


Enjoyment: 7.


While I have lobbed some fairly critical comments against the series, let me back-peddle and suggest that I am more than aware that this show is not a masterpiece, nor was it aiming to be. It was an entertaining and ridiculous premise that aimed to be fun and quick to get into, and I believe it more than succeeded. While my attention did wane every now and then, I never strayed so far that I thought of quitting, and I laughed quite hard multiple times throughout the series. I think it was a "good," anime, and while I didn't get what I wanted, I could easily claim to have gotten a fair consolation prize instead.


Overall: 7.


I'll walk away knowing I probably won't revisit this show, and while I would watch a second season, I likely won't be scouring the internet looking for confirmation of such. I think this was a good anime that did something interesting. While it did not quite live up to what I had hoped to get out of it, it most assuredly did not let me down entirely, and I think it was just a above-average good way to kill some time. I hope that if a second season ever did come to fruition, it might take a glance at the success of Shokugeki and fix some of the areas that were bothersome to me, so that the show might reach the potential I believe it has. All in all, definitely worth a watch, but do so casually. I would not recommend this if you're looking for a new obsession, keep this one in the queue for when you need a quick laugh. 


Recommendations:


1. Shokugeki (Food Wars). As I already mentioned, Ben-To would work very well as a palate cleanser or cool-down after watching Shokugeki. Although Ben-To was unique enough that I would not go so far as to suggest it was just "Food Wars Lite," or anything, they do have similar feels. Whereas Shokugeki presents an ever-present larger plotline lingering in the background, Ben-To is more simple, not really looking forward towards anything, just enjoying itself in the moment. I think if anything, you could say that Ben-To could be watched like a more casual Shokugeki.


2. Dagashi Kashi. I was not a fan of this show, but they have similarities between them. Dagashi Kashi relies on fan service a bit more than Ben-To, in my opinion, and Ben-To succeeds more as an interesting show because it does not suffer the pacing issues Dagashi has for me. They both deal with people caring far too much about common food to the point of obsession, and being carried too far because of these obsessions.

Ben-To Review
OVERALL: 6/10
PLOT: 7/10
The concept of the story is unique, honestly. However, I don't see any development in it as every episode seems to be repetitive. It is just like one boss after another. One floor after another. If you get what I mean. Well yeah, I admit that the action scenes are good and if you're the type who only want to watch an anime who fight again and again. Then you can try this. I rated it above 5 or 6 since I'm amazed on how the plot of this is unimaginable. Like for the sole purpose of getting that something, they becomebrave and fight. Maybe the message of it was if you do want something, you should fight for it.\n
CHARACTER: 5/10\n
The main character has no impact at all for me. Or it is just to cliche? The protagonists role are too common. It made me bored to watch the anime because of the character which I often see in most of the anime who have the same genre. Aside from the traits, the looks is also common. Black Hair, a masochist one, a pervert one and the like. I DON'T HATE IT. I just don't like it.\n
SOUND: 8/10\n
I don't really know how to rate sounds. But I like the opening song and the emotional song on the last episode of the series. I'm planning to download it later. The song is also exclusively for the anime, as the message of it focuses on the plot or the anime itself. The voices of the character, in my opinion, is good. I think they successfully express the emotion of the role they're trying to voice out.\n
ENJOYMENT: 6/10\n
Boringness and enjoyment is quite the same level when I watched this series. I enjoyed the fighting. And at the same time, I want to fast forward it when the fighting ends. I get the idea that even if I fast forward it, there's no significant message or scene I'd skip. But FYI, I don't skip it at all. I watched it completely.\n
ENDING: 6/10\n
This is where I burst "What?".\n
The ending of an action anime should be the final fight. That's for me. However, they skip the fighting and proceeded with the friendship thing. I expected something more exciting than the previous fighting episodes. I want more of the psycho face of that girl. But yeah, that's nowhere to be seen.

Ben-to! Is what life really should be like, and what life sometimes is.
Story: 6\10
I gave the story 6 because it didn't have much of it. However, it's been awhile since I watched the anime, so I've probably forgot a bit of the story. However.... You'll start watching this amazing anime, knowing it is about a bunch of people beating each other up for half priced Ben-to. You'll also be aware that there are good looking anime waifus for you to add to your harem. I don't think you care much for story.
Art: 10\10
I'm pretty easy going on art and sound. As long as there isn'tsomething glaringly wrong with the art, I'm happy. An example: The mouths in Your Lie in April make me shudder. Another example is how everyone is so deathly thin in some anime. Like, it's unhealthy.


The artwork in Ben-to is much better, so there's not much to say.


Sound: 10\10

I watched dub, and the dub was okay. Everyone could be heard, it wasn't like the Elfen Lied dub where everyone whispered. The timing for mouths and speech if I remember correct, was top quality.


Character: 10\10

Everyone had these well made backstories, which affected the good nicknames given to them. The Ice Queen and the lady of the lake are just two of the names given to the top dogs.


Besides the nicknames, we also get to see various interwining backgrounds between some of the characters. It might be a little cliche at times, but Ben-to isn't an anime you watch because you want a sensible plot with great character depth. I'd say it has an acceptable level of character depth, but from my memory, it isn't the best out there. The fact I can't remember the character names or all their nicknames also suggests that my memory is either betraying me, or the characters are just forgettable.


Enjoyment: 10\10

I may forget their names, their nicknames, and the story, but I'll never forgot Ben-to as a whole. The enjoyment was brilliant, because it was hilarious and showed the true savagry of humans. If shopping was like this, then I would love shopping! Wanna get strong? Shop for half priced Ben-to and fight!


The idea of these fully grown men fighting and getting their backsides handed to them by some high school girl also proved to add to the hilarity. Of course it is a anime cliche that women are gods of war who can never be harmed, even if they never went through fight training, but Ben-to just mad eit so I didn't care. It became acceptable for these men to be weaker than this girl.


Overall: 10\10

I gave it a 10\10 because this will be one I will rewatch, and it has a high priority over other anime. The score could chnage after a rewatch, if for some reason i decide it isn't as fun the second time round.


Right now, without a doubt this is a great watch, and one I'll come to see again.

Really horrible anime. Seems like the only thing is a parody. It seems as if the makers want you to take the plot seriously, but the serious vibe + ridiculousness of the actual happenings are a horrible combination.
If you're into watching very relaxed, light-hearted anime, this might be for you. But you'll be in for a surprise, as normally a light-hearted anime has light-hearted plot and minimal suspense, but in a believable situation. This anime is the opposite. Serious plot and fighting scenes, in a ridiculous situation. It is very hard to take seriously or even find comical.
If you decide to watch this anime, goodfor you. Have fun wasting however-long-before-you-drop-it of your life.

The story happens to be as deep as bowl of ramen, but that's okay you have your high school drama and gang wars what more do you need. Overall it's your everyday run of the millharem/fighting anime 6/10

Waring this review may contain spoilers.
First impressions, so we got harem show where people fight for half price bento's and there is some heram shit going down sounds fun enough.
Side note a bento is a Japanese lunch box  in case you didn't know that.
Story, 6/10
So bento is about the main character who goes to a shop to get himself some half price bento. But then gets his ass kicked by a girl when he try's to get one.
After that he soon learns that one doesn't just simply get himself a half price bento one must earn it though  honorable combat and blood shed.This contest of strength and willpower is known as the bento brawl where the wolfs get to fed  and the dogs go home hungry. 


So to sunrise bento it pretty much about these group of people who beat  the living shit out of each other for what is essentially half price food, and I thinking to myself man this is really stupid this will never work and to my amazement I find that this actually works.

Now I am not saying that this best story ever made  because it's extremely simplistic in both ideas and presentation. but I think what makes it work is that it takes the battle shounen mentality and compressed it into one of the most mundane of tasks which is shopping.


This show also includes some harem/school life  elements as well 

And your properly  thinking that it's going to be one of those things where the main character a bata male and has all these badass girls protecting him well if you thought that then your wrong because it more like they kick his ass and then he kicks there ass and they become apart of his harem so it's like a reverse Kung fu harem and the school life parts are self explanatory.


One thing I think is quite fun about this show is that 

For one the characters seem to take this whole bento brawl thing  very seriously. For example you got characters having monologues about honor  and way of the warrior type of shit.


But a negative I got to say about it is that it really doesn't have any type of logic to it and that kind thing kind of bothered  me a bit.  So pretty much turn off your brain while watching this show.





Characters, 6/10


The main character can be pretty much be sum up as the normal high school student who is a bit of a pervert and likes old school games and is a bit bata male at first.

but after a while he starts becoming a bit of a badass in his own way 


The side characters are pretty much two dimensional at the most.


But they are quite the interesting bunch of .......  no interesting isn't really the word I would use probably I should  use the word zany so the are a zany bunch  of characters.


They all have some personally even though it's really basic.





Art, 7/10


The animation was very well done it isn't at that God level of animation quality but it looks very nice.

It also has very bright colors that is uses.


It also has some very well done fight animation as well.


It has a very genneric art style that you seen it once you seen it all.


The characters designs are also generic as well.



Sound, 6/10 


It has an ok op that fits the tone nicely.


It's ost to me is pretty generic.  nothing really stands out about the ost.




Enjoyment, 7/10 


So this show some what blowed me away of how fun this show was.


I like that it's got people fighting over stupid shit.



I also liked the  really cool steet fighting.


I also found the characters to be fun as well.



Overall, 6/10


So overall if your looking a dumb fun anime then you will find bento to be one kick ass of a show. But if your the kind of person who like his shows a bit more serious and have logic behind then this show won't really be your cup of tea.

Before I write this review I would just like to state that this is my opinion and if you might agree or disagree with all of it or most of it.
Review:
Ben-To is a Japaneses lunch which in our case the main plot device in our show. I will say i enjoyed Ben-To a hell of a lot more than i should of but that still doesn't make that good. The plot doesn't really make sense but it's still better than that bland anime that people are still making carbon copies of. I think the main reason I enjoyed Ben-To so much was it's character progression.In this anime you start off with the MC not able to fight what so ever but eventually making a "NAME" for himself let that name be good or bad. The faults is that it has so many cliches in it I kinda lost interest in a couple of episodes. The problem is it's uniqueness didn't need as many cliches as it had made me get bored at times. The cliches in this anime vary from cliche boob girls to cliche douche bags but are caring on the inside all the way to loli that is very clumsy. See what I mean these are the token anime characters. All in all I still enjoyed the anime it was a lot of fun especially with the changing conflict. I personally suggest this anime if you have down time but it's not a drop everything and watch this kinda anime.

Well, I didn't expect much from this anime. It was occasionally funny but not enough humor to make me laugh a lot. The story is surely different from what I thought it would turn out to be be like but I didn't drop it because the action scenes were really nice.
To a certain extent this anime made me feel like being a part of the brawl they partake in procuring half priced bento. I'm sure not everyone can make enough money to buy good enough food at the regular selling price so this anime kept me interested enough to finish watching it.
Well if there's onething this anime did to me is make me feel like I want to learn to prepare bento meals for myself and my friend. So I'm going to go ahead and do that. Overall, the anime was fine. I wouldn't watch it again, though.

Fighting bloody battles over bento boxes in the supermarket... yes! that's what this anime is about!! Honestly, when I see anime like this one, I think the manga/anime authors are running out of ideas here for their creation.
Ben-To has no story to begin with. Almost every episode is all about people (teen or adult) fighting over bento boxes at half the original price offered at various supermarkets. That's Ben-To in a nutshell.
I would have rated it lower overall, but the bloody fistfights were at least enjoyable. So I decided to score it 5/10.
If you have nothing else to do, you can watch it as atime pass. Otherwise, I don't recommend this anime if you're looking for something with a story.

This anime has a weird but a fun plot! It's a story which isn't fictitious but based on activities in daily life! I liked the plot as it had action and it somehow reflected what people usually feel when carrying out their daily activities (as if they are fighting a battle); it's like the visualization was created just to express those feelings! It's fight for food and if the food is expensive but available at low price - fight until you get it!
I felt weird, although, during certain parts of the episodes.
The characters had some unique personalities and I liked some of the characters. AlsoI liked the way the characters were given nicknames. I also liked the ending theme music!\n
Overall, I enjoyed watching the anime!

Going into Ben-To, I was expecting a light-hearted and ridiculous series, and that's exactly what I got. It does what it says on the tin. They were several aspects that made this a very enjoyable anime to watch, but it was also let down on a few things - one in particular. So I'll go through three key points (from best to worst) and try to explain the 6/10 rating I've given it as best I can.
1. Characters - easily the strongest force in this series. I wouldn't describe any of the characters as 'deep' or 'wholesome', but they don't need to be. They're notcomplicated by anything superfluous, and any/all past history is directly relevant to the absurd present-day pursuit of half-price bento. Oshiroi is a great new riff on a classic (but overdone) stereotype, with some of her outbursts genuinely funny (I'll get to the dub later). The Ice Witch immediately had me groaning, until it became clear that her title has nothing to do with any kind of frosty traits, and that she was just a normal person. She wasn't Tsundre, because her coldness literally lasted one episode, and I found this really refreshing. And Sato is your average regular teenage male protagonist, but somehow more likeable that many. Perhaps it's because whenever he's called a 'pervert', it's because there is some real truth in the matter, but the proportions to which each situation is blown out of context is both hilariously over the top, and really not his fault at all.


2. The Dub - I generally take Dub over Sub, because I like to do things like drawing and messaging while watching shows, so I prefer not to have to read the screen constantly. My immediate thoughts for Ben-To's dub were: "This voice-acting is awful" and "This does not translate well enough to dub". But a few episodes in, and I'd completely forgotten all my concerns. This is to the character's credit more than anything - as I said before, Oshiroi provides many comedic moments, and it's the perfect combination Felecia Angelle's searingly annoying tone and some expertly adapted dialogue that makes this so. Sometimes annoying characters can be forgiven if they are funny enough, and this is definitely such a case. The clunkiness of Sato's dialogue soon disappears as you get used to the ridiculous shenanigans that this series is filled with, and surprisingly, there's not a lot that goes over the head of a western audience member.


3. The Story. Oh, the story. This is where Ben-To really disappoints, I'm afraid. Before I started watching, I was thinking "I know it's only 12 episodes, but how can you sustain an anime about fighting over Ben-To to more than a 4-parter?" The initial introductory story was enjoyable, but it found itself with nowhere to go, so onto a new, completely left-field story... which lasted two episodes. And the rest was surrounded by two new characters, embedded in mystery, and the pay off was just so underwhelming. Honestly, it became thoroughly tedious to watch these boring twins go about their business, when there was no sign of their actual motives until the penultimate episode, and everything they did seemed such a farce. They were the worst characters, because they came so late in a cast of strong individuals. It was SO difficult to care what happened with them, and it was painful that the whole second half of the series seemed to somehow revolve around them. Their storyline's ending was fair enough, but it could have been resolved in half the time with a quarter of the discombobulation their deployment caused.


Which brings us onto the ending. Which took place with one of the main characters completely out of action. Which not only ended the series, but also the boring and overly long final storyline involving those awful aforementioned twins. A series like Ben-To, especially being the size it is, really needed to go out with a BANG! And it didn't. The ending felt like a perfect way to end a mid-series arc, and was a great way of adding a little extra to characters we feel we know pretty well at this point... but to end the series? No, it left me quite dissatisfied. And the worst part is that I could see it coming. As this final storyline last 6 episodes out of 12, I could tell that the pacing was off, and that it was going to leave me underwhelmed. Ben-To's biggest weakness is that it was innately short on ways to sustain a story, and it was a problem that wasn't troubleshooted well at all.


So, all-in-all, I gave Ben-To a 6/10. Every element except for the story had it set up to be an 8 or a 9, but unfortunately it's just one of those things.

This anime was alright. Somewhat forgettable and the characters were pretty generic. I mean it is an echii/harem anime and they(for the most part) follow a cookie cutter strategy with the girls and the main character.  The characters were somewhat likable and the anime did have its funny moments. 
There is one thing in this anime that really did piss me off. Something had happened to some character(s) and it had scarred them for a while and when it was revealed to the audience, it did not live up to the way the anime was trying to make it out to be.
Overall, the animeis alright. Had its good moments, it had its annoying moments. Right now, I am stuck between giving it a 5 or 6 and I feel that as I watch more anime, I'll be able to give it a score i am comfortable with. For now I am fine with giving this anime a 6/10.

Ben-To isn't the first anime about food but it is one of the most enjoyable I've seen in awhile.But that being said the "Food"in Ben-To isn't what the show is really about you could easily replace the bento's with magic orbs or lost  treasure ,and the unlined theme would be the same "Honor" in battle the battle just happen to be over food.The fight are enjoyable and fun to watch add the characters each with there own traits that makes them likable and great to see in interactions with one another.And  even with the seemly forced in "romantic" and  ecchi moments thatseem to pop up out of no where and disappear just as fast.Ben-to is still on of my favorite new animes of the season and one I look forward to finishing and  one I would recommend to anyone looking for a good fight anime with a good story to goo along with it

Now I'm not very aesthetic in general, and am not one to base an anime off of menial things such as the art and soundtrack, which were both very good. I actually like to base an anime off what it deserves, in terms of plot, comedy if it had it, things not apparent in the artwork, and using art/sound to support it.
Onwards,
Story: 8
I give the story an 8 due to the fact that the premise on its own is completely ridiculous. They go relatively in-depth with it, which was something I did not expect. When I heard that there were light novels and an animeabout people having a battle royale over half-priced lunch boxes, I first thought they were stupid, and then contemplated how they could make a 10+ volumes and 12 episodes of it. After progressing through, I found out how, and they did a pretty great job at solidifying everything. Other than the idea itself though, it's your standard anime.


Art: 8

The art was pretty great. If you like moe overboard, then this is definitely for you. It's not my thing, but ho hum. Everything was fairly detailed and the fight scenes were animated very well.


Sound: 10

The best part of the anime. The two openings, ending, grocery store songs, and fight songs were all amazing. They fit the atmosphere extremely well, and even when they didn't, it was pretty comedic. The soundtrack and B-sides of the singles are awesome, so I highly recommend that even if you don't watch the anime, get the soundtrack and/or singles.


Character: 6

Characters were generic, save for the 'novelist', but somewhat fun in the way they interacted with each other. I can't really say anything else about them to be honest.


Enjoyment: 5

Now here's the kicker, if all of these were mended together well, I would have no problem enjoying this anime wholeheartedly.


However, the amount of unnecessary ecchi/fanservice roadblocks in this anime detracts from its score greatly. Hell, there was even a full episode about ecchi/fanservice just smack in the middle of everything. From a comedy factor, I found it was very lackluster, save for the yaoi fangirl. There were maybe one or two laugh out loud parts in each episode, while the rest were failed joke attempts (all rehashed cliche joke scenarios from other anime) that were forced upon you, wasting your time while you waited for the plot to continue.


Overall: 6

I was very disappointed, as this anime could have been so much more. While the premise and other things related to its production were excellent, it ended up like any other generic ecchi/harem anime.

Ben-To, This anime is definitely one of the most funny, enjoyable, and awesome animes i have watched yet. To say the truth when i would go through the top list of anime sites and i would see Ben-To with such a high rank, I would ask myself why on earth is an anime that is about people fighting for food so highly rated?
And every time i saw it on a top list I would ask the question because truthfully the concept is just stupid, but one day i told myself if its so high on the ratings I might as well try it. So Idid, and it was completely awesome and so well done from the first minute of the anime to the last. I don't usually say this but if you happen to have some free time and feel like watching a lot awesome action with some hilarious moments you have to watch Ben-To.


Story-(10) To me a well made and very unique idea makes a good story line. And this definitely has the most unique idea for a story line that I have ever seen and would have never expected this kind of story from any anime. Truthfully expected it to be really boring and bad, but it was really good :DD


Art-(10) The art was perfect and combined with the really good sound it just gave the anime a big boost and also gave me the urge to watch this anime despite the fact that i thought it would be boring.


Characters-(9) The characters were just hilarious at moments and awesome at others, and with the personalities that fit the characters perfectly it really enforces how good the anime can be.


All in all, this anime is a must watch anime and is worth the time. And also one thing to say before i finish and that is never judge a book by its cover and this anime is a perfect example for that.

Have fun and hoped my review helped you. Thanks

Ben-To was really fun to watch. It has a ridiculous, over the top, and maybe innovative plot which holds together the anime. Without much money and maybe not much luck either, the protagonist finds himself in a fight for half-priced food. And when I say fight, I mean fight.
  The anime goes through themes such as pride and respect in its own way. It tells that, even in the madness that a brawl for half-priced food is, there are unwritten rules and maybe what you could call etiquette. I would go as far as saying it makes the battle for half-priced fooda sport, without revenge or hate in mind, just food.


  The fights are illustrated and animated in a very fluid manner. It does get a little violent, but only in the graphic side.The music which accompanies the animation has a great feel, I think the rhythm is just perfect. Sometimes you can't even tell it's there because it fits so well.


  Beyond the primary plot of Ben-To, there is nothing much to say. Most of the anime is filled with fan service, or what you could call a rich high-school student protagonist life. A rather unlucky high-school student life, filled with beatings and awkward situations. The character development doesn't go very far. Maybe because it's short, or maybe because it's just unnecessary. Not any considerable back story, and perhaps not enough screen time for all characters, which are mostly girls.


  TL;DR Ben-To is a fun to watch, nicely animated anime that is about food, fights, and high-school girls. It doesn't have any plot, story or character development and it doesn't need them. The fun had in Ben-To is from either from unlucky style comedy, or from the brave style action.

"The weak are prey, and the strong dine well."
Imagine what people would be like if we still had to struggle to survive as in ancient times. Had to fight for that which would sustain and strengthen us. Had to be willing to push forward against fear and uncertainty to great heights of power and take what we want.
That is the way of the bento wolf.
Japanese animation has had one iconic item in most anime since the inception of the medium taken from real life: BENTO!!!!
 A boxed pre prepared meal that is usually depicted as being either made at home or bought from asupermarket and consumed by kids and teens of pre college age. As has been the case for a long time, prices have been rediculous in Japan and have created a very strange state for people to live in. Hence when there is food that is half price, and in bento form laying around to be taken, there is no shortage of people willign to step up to the plate. \n\n
Enter a generation of young people who literally fight with one and other to keep off starvation by laying low(not dead though) those around them in a supermarkets half price bento section to take whichever meal they want. But many are there to stand in ones way of not only nutrition but a primal urge to strike out on ones own and take what the law of nature says is the right of any strong enough to take it. \n\n
 Our protagonist is a young man who must decide if it is better to have a few scrapes or starve and vows to become a true 'wolf'. Sadly he is fairly pathetic considering he can fight quite well in a supermarket, but girls wipe the floor with him everywhere else....(*sigh* classic cheesy anime male..)..our poor poor misrepresented gender. LOL\n\n
A seemingly plotless show to the uninitiated, but do not be fooled. There is as much comedy as dead seriousness about the intent to fight for ones food in this show. What is created is an enjoyable time spent relearning what our ancestors must have gone through in an unimaginably archaic time and why they saw nothing wrong with it. Laughs, a tad bit o romance and some good fights follow after an admittedly funny plot concept. \n\n
 LET THERE BE BENTO!!!!!

Hey Mates, Vampmaster with more stuff here.
Let's jump right into it, and as starters i would like to say not enough episodes.
I really liked this and i would like to see the characters develop even more, but if they got to do that there is also the risk that they are not as unique any more.
I love the characters and to meaning behind the very random storyline.
I am known on some other sites to have a "Golden eye" to find a meaning behind a very blunt, non-thinking and weird storyline.
Some of my friends liked how to Satou was strong, confident and how all the girlslooked up to him. But that's not true. After what i can see it's actually the other way around. Yes the girls may like him, but at the same time they fond over him like a caring mother. And if you look close enough does not argue over him being a "barkling/dog" (beginner). It's only at the end he tries to reverse it and tries to be the caring parent. And more episodes could reveal if he tries to reverse that with all the people or just for Yarizui.

While Satou being the most twisted person, we also have Oshiro who makes the series seem less serious, in other words, she is the supporting character that only exists as a joke, to lighten the mood, and hide the true plot from all none "Golden eye" anime-lovers.

One of the best things with this series is the pride theme of it all. The titles wolves, dogs, pigs and so on, are the things that actually are hard to find in a lot of other series. You could relate it to the military these days, but that doesn't seem fair. I think it's more psychological than that, again with the Satou who is called "barkling", he is a wolf though, because i obeys the rules, have gotten a bento and even a title. Yet they call him "barkling", and he doesn't argue over it, that is because he knows that he isn't as strong as everybody else, he starts out relying on them, and it ends up with one person actually relies on him. And that second he probably would begin calling himself a wolf, instead of dog. Because wolves may hunt together, but it is always survival of the fittest.

Enough with the story and character.


The art is right now a very common and popular style. It makes more people want to watch it.


The sound are great because a times when it gets serious, they cut background music of and it suddenly hits you how serious that moment is.


I loved it, and pretty much anybody could do that, ecchi lovers, comedy fans, serious viewers, action people and normal people who cares for all genres. It contains all genres, and the hiddes slice of life makes it perfect for people who liked fx. Clannad because it has its moments that comedy fans would not could see because of it's clever disguise.


Overall everybody would could love it, and it is a really brain-crusher for those who loves slice of life and the principal of pride.


So the scores are high and it would could turn all ways with a new season.


Look out for more reviewers from me in the future, i don't write many here i only write for the best animes on animelist.net.

i quite enjoyed the idea behind it cute girls + well executed fights + comedy. it was so close to being a hit but it was missing one critical thing and due to that it fell apart completely. there was no solid story line, it was just people fighting over lunchboxes with cute girls and a weird harem.
The anime was visually okay it just lacked a proper story line, well that and a decent main character. 
how can you have an anime about fighting when the main character is a masochistic wimp. i'm sure people will say there's nothing wrong with a perverted wimp [thatjust lets people beat him up for no reason] when its in a harem setting but the harem still kinda sucked. don't get me wrong the characters  were quite good as individuals i really liked sen, inoue and the wizard they all had they're redeeming qualities well except sato.\n
honestly i think what pissed me off the most was the fact that he kept getting beaten up for no reason i know its an anime that revolves around fighting but he'd only get beaten up OUTSIDE the fight scenes. him vs people in a fight = awesome. him walking outside his classroom = owned for talking to oshiroi. wtf!?\n\n
all in all i'd say it was fairly enjoyable i know i complained a bit but like i said at the beginning its only major flaw is the random jigsaw story and the main character but the latter is more of me just not liking wimpy main characters.\n\n
basically if you have loads of free time watch it, otherwise don't bother your not missing much.
